Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <FtrSaroth> Ok, the concepts more new to me was the zk_SNARKs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @FtrSaroth yes, Venezuela has perhaps the most to benefit from Hush, along with Catalonia

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Once messages go on the blockchain, they are there forever, once notarized. This is protected by BTC hashrate security via Delayed-proof-of-work

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> You can prove things in the future, maybe to a judge or your employer or the gov or ...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's up to you

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> if you don't want that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> you can make your own private Hush network that nobody can access, and chat on that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we have solutions for all use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Privatoshi> This is what I like to hear

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Privatoshi> I trust dPOW

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> me too

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Privatoshi> HushList protocol is better than signal protocol, IMO

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> they solve slightly different use cases

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> signal proto is helped by a central server to introduce Alice + Bob, then alice + bob talk directly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> HushList proto is p2p

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> very different, deep down

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> but similar goals

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and they can be integrated, potentially. but hushlist is somewhat a competitor to signal (Richochet) protocol

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Privatoshi> @FtrSaroth The basic idea is, to provide encrypted, secure mailing lists.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Tomyris> @dukeleto I think it's a good feature to increase the adoption, it's not mandatory anyway. It's a great use-case if you ask me. For the websites or businesses who would like to get payments in CCX, it would be a great option as well. You can always get a random name.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Privatoshi> I'm running SDA on my ChromeBook

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Tomyris> If we would like to provide the privacy for everyone, these kind of features are needed.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Tomyris> Unfortunately, privacy projects don't think much about how to improve adoption. For example, for normal people who don't understand technology, privacy coins are complicated. To make it widespread, you should provide ease of use.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Tomyris> I think you should think about adoption. Just a suggestion.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Privatoshi you might be the first one!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Tomyris you make valid points about adoption. Adoption and privacy are often at odds and every chain must decide the middle path to walk between them

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> vanity addresses seem to solve that use case, i would tell people to just do that. we do need better support for them, it's CLI only currently

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Tomyris> @dukeleto Exactly. I think the best coin won't be the coin with the best privacy only, it will be the coin that combines with privacy and adoption best.
